The Matching Hypothesis
_____1. I do not receive as much touch in my life as normal people.
_____2. I receive a normal, healthy amount of touch from people.
_____3. Human touch is not a daily occurrence in my life.
_____4. Touch from other people is a very common and natural part of my daily life.
_____5. I often go for days without being touched by someone.
_____6. I often feel like I’m untouchable because of the lack of touch from others in my life.
_____7. I receive a variety of forms of touch from a variety of different people.
_____8. I can go long periods of time without being touched by another person.
_____9. There are days when I would do anything just to be touched by someone.
_____10. I have longed for the touch of another person, any person.
_____11. Some days I long to be held, but have no one to hold me.
_____12. I often wish I could get more hugs from others.
_____13. I’ve engaged in sexual behaviors for the pure purpose of being touched by someone.
_____14. I would never engage in sex with someone, just to be touched.
SCORING: To compute your scores follow the instructions below:
Absence of Touch
Step One: Add scores for items 1, 3, 5, 6, & 8_____
Step Two: Add scores for items 2, 4, & 7_____
Step Three: Add 18 to Step One._____
Step Four: Subtract the score for Step two from the score for Step Three._____
Longing for Touch
Step One: Add scores for items 9, 10, 11, & 12_____
Sex for Touch
Step One: Add scores for item 13_____
Step Two: Add scores for item 14_____
Step Three: Add 6 to Step One._____
Step Four: Subtract the score for Step Two from the score for Step Three._____
Interpreting Your Score:

_____1. I often avoid having all or part of my body seen by others.
_____2. My sex life has not been affected by concerns related to my physical appearance.
_____4. I do not worry that my body isn’t sufficiently lean or muscular.
_____5. I am comfortable showing my body in public situations.
_____6. I often eat alone because I don’t want people to know how much or how little I am eating.
_____7. My self-esteem is not influenced by my weight.
_____8. I worry a lot about how I look.
_____9. I am generally not self-conscious of how I look when I am around others.
_____10. When people tell me that I look good, I generally think they are lying.
SCORING: To compute your scores follow the instructions below:
Step One: Add scores for items 1, 3, 6, 8, & 10_____
Step Two: Add scores for items 2, 4, 5, 7, & 9_____
Step Three: Add 30 to Step 1._____
Step Four: Subtract the score for Step two from the score for Step Three._____

Kentucky Journal of Communication  125
Silent Signals: Enhancing Communication
Skills through Nonverbal Cues
Great Ideas for Teaching Students
G.I.F.T. Submission: Great Ideas For Teaching
Hayden V. Coombs
Braden H. Bagley
Hayden V. Coombs, Southern Utah University, haydencoombs@suu.edu
Braden Bagley,  Southern Utah University, bradenbagley@suu.edu
Kentucky Journal of Communication
Abstract
is GIFT article presents an engaging classroom activity designed to enhance students'
understanding of nonverbal communication, a vital aspect of eective interpersonal interaction. e
activity immerses students in exercises that require them to communicate solely through nonverbal
posture, and eye contact. By prohibiting verbal communication, students develop creativity and
adaptability in conveying and interpreting messages, improving their overall communicative
competence. is approach aligns with GIFT principles, providing innovative, classroom-tested
strategies to enhance student learning through practical and engaging methods.
Keywords: Nonverbal Communication, Interpersonal Communication, Interactive, GIFT
ISSN: 1533-3140 © 2024 Kentucky Communication Association
Objective
e objective of this activity is to enhance students' understanding of nonverbal
students will learn to recognize and interpret various nonverbal cues, such as body language, facial
expressions, gestures, posture, and eye contact, which oen convey more information and emotional
nuance than words alone. is activity also aims to develop students' ability to communicate
nonverbal means, students will gain insights into the subtleties of human communication, becoming
more observant and empathetic, thereby improving their ability to convey and interpret messages
Silent Signals
Kentucky Journal of Communication  126
in diverse contexts. is approach aligns with the principles of GIFT (Great Ideas for Teaching )
articles, which focus on innovative, classroom-tested strategies designed to enhance student
learning through practical and engaging methods (Barton & Coombs, 2023).
Rationale
Nonverbal communication is a critical component of the communication process,
comprising up to 93% of communication eectiveness (Mehrabian, 1972). is activity is designed
to immerse students in nonverbal communication, highlighting its importance and encouraging
them to explore and reect on dierent nonverbal cues, such as body language, facial expressions,
and object language. By engaging in nonverbal communication exercises, students become more
attuned to the subtleties of body language, facial expressions, and gestures, enhancing their
observational skills and empathetic understanding.
Nonverbal communication encompasses various forms of conveying information without
the use of words, including body language, facial expressions, gestures, posture, and eye contact.
According to Bunglowala and Bunglowala (2015), nonverbal communication is more inuential
than verbal communication, comprising approximately 93% of the communicative process.
is signicant percentage highlights the necessity for educators to understand and eectively
use nonverbal cues in the classroom. Mehrabian (1972) emphasizes the impact of nonverbal
communication in expressing emotions and attitudes, suggesting that 55% of communication is
through body language, 38% through vocal elements such as tone, and only 7% through words.
is underscores the importance of nonverbal signals in establishing rapport, managing the
classroom, and enhancing the learning experience.
Current students oen exhibit deciencies in nonverbal communication skills, which
can hinder both their interpersonal interactions and professional development, particularly
in workplace settings where nonverbal cues are essential. Studies indicate that students may
lack awareness of how nonverbal behaviors, such as body language, facial expressions, and
gestures, convey critical information during communication (Dash & Davis, 2022). is
deciency, exacerbated by an overreliance on verbal communication, leaves their nonverbal
skills underdeveloped despite their importance in reinforcing or even replacing verbal messages.
In professional environments, nonverbal communication is crucial for expressing emotions,
intentions, and fostering trust and leadership (Bonaccio et al., 2016). Misunderstanding these
subtle cues, as Patterson et al. (2023) argue, can lead to ineective communication, damaging
workplace relationships and undermining organizational success. Educators and researchers alike
have observed that students are oen unaware of how their nonverbal behaviors, such as eye
H. Coombs, B. Bagley
Kentucky Journal of Communication  127
contact and posture, aect their interactions, further creating barriers to eective communication
(Okon, 2011). Addressing these deciencies through training is essential for enhancing students'
overall competencies, enabling them to better interpret and utilize nonverbal communication in
both social and professional settings, thus improving team dynamics and fostering high-quality
relationships (Phutela, 2015).
Nonverbal teaching strategies involve the deliberate use of body language, facial
expressions, eye contact, gestures, and other nonverbal cues to enhance teaching eectiveness.
Wahyuni (2017) highlights that eective nonverbal communication can improve academic
performance and foster a positive learning environment. Key nonverbal strategies include
maintaining eye contact to engage students and demonstrate condence, using positive facial
expressions to create a welcoming atmosphere, employing gestures to emphasize points and
illustrate concepts, adopting an open posture to appear approachable, and moving around the
classroom to increase interaction. Nonverbal immediacy behaviors, such as eye contact and smiling,
are associated with increased student motivation and aective learning (Pogue & Ahyun, 2006).
Additionally, eective use of nonverbal communication can help manage classroom behavior and
create a more engaging and interactive learning experience (Wahyuni, 2017).
is activity leverages the power of experiential learning to deepen students' understanding of
nonverbal communication, which constitutes a signicant portion of human interaction. Practicing
interactions in diverse social and professional contexts.
Activity Description
is nonverbal communication activity is designed to immerse students in the realm of
nonverbal cues, enhancing their ability to convey and interpret information without the use of
them to express their thoughts and emotions solely through nonverbal means, with the prohibition
of speaking beginning as soon as they enter the classroom and lasting until they exit. While engaged
to reect on the nonverbal communication skills practiced during the class. In the following class,
cues. is exercise not only highlights the signicance of nonverbal communication but also fosters
creativity and adaptability, ultimately improving students' overall communicative competence.
Student engagement begins with a silent review of their self-produced chapter notes, either
typed or hand-written, which they took from the textbook prior to class. Working with a partner,
Silent Signals
Kentucky Journal of Communication  128
written notes. is exercise is designed to help students recognize the eectiveness and nuances of
nonverbal communication in everyday interactions.
Following the chapter review, students will explore the concept of "object language" by
examining and interpreting the messages conveyed by dierent objects in the classroom. ey will
make a list of at least ten items, describing the nonverbal messages these items convey. is task
encourages students to recognize how material possessions and their presentation can communicate
various social and personal messages.
Next, students watch a silent television program, during which they will analyze and
document the storyline, character interactions, and emotions through observed nonverbal cues such
as facial expressions, eye contact, body movements, and physical appearance. I found any computer-
animated show with the audio muted to work well for this part of the activity. is exercise enhances
their ability to read and interpret nonverbal signals in media and real-life scenarios.
e activity concludes with students analyzing advertisements with minimal written
content to identify the main themes and create captions based on the nonverbal elements depicted.
ese advertisements will either have minimal text or have the text entirely removed. e students
will take note of what they thought was the goal of each advertisement.
Preparation
Preparing for this nonverbal communication activity requires several thoughtful steps to
outlining each task and the sequence in which they will be performed. is sheet should clearly
state the rules, especially the prohibition on verbal communication, and provide spaces for students
to write their responses. Additionally, placing "DO NOT SPEAK" signs on the classroom doors
before anyone enters sets the tone for the activity and reinforces the importance of adhering to
nonverbal communication throughout the class period.
Next, sourcing appropriate media for the activity is crucial. Find a silent television show
or clip that eectively showcases nonverbal cues such as facial expressions, body movements,
and gestures. e selected clip should be engaging and varied enough to provide ample material
for analysis. Ensure the clip is cued up and ready to play without any technical issues. For the
advertisement analysis segment, identify nine advertisements that primarily use imagery and
minimal text to convey their messages. ese ads should be diverse in style and content to expose
H. Coombs, B. Bagley
Kentucky Journal of Communication  129
students to a range of nonverbal communication techniques. Print and display these advertisements
prominently at the front of the room for easy access during the activity.
In addition to media preparation, the classroom environment should be arranged to
they are visible and accessible to all participants. ese objects might include items like clothing,
jewelry, art pieces, or everyday objects that can convey dierent messages. Lastly, ensure you have
implements and paper for note-taking. By meticulously preparing each aspect of the activity,
instructors create a structured and immersive environment that enhances students' understanding
and appreciation of nonverbal communication.
Debrief
e debrief for this activity will take place during the next class meeting, providing
students with a chance to reect on their experiences and solidify their understanding of nonverbal
communication principles. I typically begin the next class by reminding students of the activities
they participated in previously and explain the importance of reecting on their experiences to
enhance their learning.
Start the debrief by inviting students to share their initial reactions and feelings about
the nonverbal communication activity. Ask questions such as, "What was the most challenging
discussion will help students process their emotions and experiences while providing insights into
the diverse ways they approached the tasks.
Next, guide the discussion to specic activities from the previous class meeting. Begin
with the chapter review exercise, asking students to describe how they communicated their favorite
parts of the chapter without using words. Encourage them to share which nonverbal strategies
were most eective and any misunderstandings that occurred. Move on to the "object language"
task, prompting students to discuss the messages they inferred from various objects and how these
interpretations diered among their peers. Highlight the signicance of context in understanding
nonverbal cues and how personal experiences can inuence interpretations.
Transition to the media analysis portion by asking students to reect on the silent video.
Discuss how they identied the storyline, character emotions, and interactions solely through
Silent Signals
Kentucky Journal of Communication  130
nonverbal cues. Emphasize the power of nonverbal communication in media and storytelling.
Similarly, discuss the advertisement analysis, encouraging students to share their captions and
interpretations. Highlight how advertisers use visual elements to convey messages without relying
on text and how this relates to their observations during the activity.
Conclude the debrief by discussing the overall impact of the activity on their
understanding of nonverbal communication. Ask students to consider how their perceptions
have changed and how they can apply these insights in everyday interactions, both personally and
professionally. Encourage them to think about how they can continue to develop their nonverbal
communication skills and be more mindful of the nonverbal signals they send and receive. is
reective debrief reinforces the learning objectives and empowers students to apply these essential
communication skills beyond the classroom, enhancing their interpersonal eectiveness.
Appraisal
One of its primary strengths of this activity is its ability to engage students in active
of information but active participants in their learning process. is engagement fosters a deeper
understanding of nonverbal communication principles and encourages students to apply these
concepts in real-time. Additionally, the activity provides practical experience in interpreting and
using nonverbal cues, which is crucial for developing eective communication skills. Students learn
to rely on and interpret body language, facial expressions, gestures, and other nonverbal signals,
enhancing their overall communicative competence. Moreover, the activity encourages critical
thinking and reection on communication processes. By analyzing their nonverbal interactions
and those of their peers, students gain insights into the complexities of nonverbal communication
and its impact on interpersonal relationships. is reection helps them become more aware of
their nonverbal behaviors and the messages they convey. It also promotes an understanding of how
dierent contexts and individual dierences can inuence the interpretation of nonverbal cues,
fostering empathy and improving their ability to communicate eectively in diverse situations.
Despite its strengths, the activity does have some limitations. One potential limitation is
the need for more class time to allow for thorough reection and discussion. While the activity
itself can be completed within a class period, the debrieng and reective discussion may require
Another limitation is that some students may nd nonverbal communication challenging without
prior practice. Students who are less comfortable or familiar with nonverbal communication may
struggle initially, which could aect their condence and participation in the activity.
H. Coombs, B. Bagley
Kentucky Journal of Communication  131
To address these limitations and enhance the activity's eectiveness, variations can
be introduced. One variation is to include activities that involve nonverbal communication in
group settings. Group exercises can provide additional opportunities for students to practice and
observe nonverbal communication in a collaborative environment, making the experience more
dynamic and inclusive. Another variation is to use dierent types of media, such as silent lms or
image-based social media posts, for analysis. ese media can oer diverse examples of nonverbal
communication in action and cater to dierent learning preferences, making the activity more
engaging and comprehensive.

Kentucky Journal of Communication  132
